subsection.p: We'll use number lines to review operations on signed numbers.

subsection.title: Adding Two Numbers with Opposite Signs
subsection.p: Suppose you have debts of $9, and assets of $6. (Your "assets" are your possessions.) What is your net worth? We can model this situation by the sum -9+(+6) where debts are represented by negative numbers and assets by positive numbers. If you use your $6 to pay off part of your debt, you will still owe $3, so your net worth is -$3. It makes sense that if your debts are greater than your assets, your net worth is negative.

assemblage.p:
Illustrate the sum (-9)+(+6) on a number line.
Graph the first number, -9, as shown below.
Move 6 units in the positive direction, or to the right.
This brings us to the sum, -3. Thus, (-9)+(+6)=-3.

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: In the example above, we see that the sum has the same sign as the number with the larger absolute value. (Can you explain this in terms of debts and assets?) When the two numbers have opposite signs, we find the value of the sum by subtracting the absolute values of the two numbers.

ol.label: a
ol.li: The two numbers have opposite signs, so we subtract 5 from 9 to get 4, then make the answer positive, because +9 has a larger absolute value than -5. Thus, (-5)+(+9)=4.
We subtract 5 from 9 to get 4, then make the answer negative, because -9 has a larger absolute value than +5. Thus,(+5)+(-9)=-4.

statement.p: What is the absolute value of a number?

answer.p: The unsigned part of the number.

subsection.p: We now have two rules for adding signed numbers.

ol.li: To add two numbers with the same sign, add their absolute values. The sum has the same sign as the numbers.
To add two numbers with opposite signs, subtract their absolute values. The sum has the same sign as the number with the larger absolute value.

assemblage.p:
Illustrate the sum 9+(-5) on a number line.
Plot 9 on the number line.
Move 5 units in the negative direction, or to the left.
The sum is 4.

Illustrate the sum 9-(+5) on a number line.
Plot 9 on the number line.
Move 5 units to the left, to indicate subtraction.
The result is 4. The picture is identical to the graph above.

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: We see that subtracting a positive number has the same result as adding the negative number with the same absolute value. Thus, to subtract a positive number, we add its opposite.

subsection.title: Subtracting a Negative Number
subsection.p: When we add a negative number we move to the left on the number line. There are only two directions we can move on a number line, so when we subtract a negative number we must move to the right.

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: Notice that 5-(-3)=8 ~~~~~ \text{and} ~~~~~5+(+3)=8 Subtracting a negative number has the same result as adding the positive number with the same absolute value. Thus, to subtract a negative number, we add its opposite.

statement.p: True or False: -x always represents a negative number. Give an example to support your answer.
Subtracting a negative number is the same as their absolute values.

subsection.p: From the examples above, we see that to subtract any number, positive or negative, we add its opposite. We can do this in steps as follows.

assemblage.title: Rules for Subtracting Integers
assemblage.p:
To subtract b from a:
Change the sign of b.
Change the subtraction to addition.
Proceed as in addition.

subsection.p: This rule tells us that we can rewrite every subtraction problem as an addition problem by changing the sign of the second number.

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: At first it may be difficult to understand why subtracting a negative number is the same as adding a positive number. Try thinking in terms of debts and assets. For example, suppose you have $25 in your wallet, and you have $5 in your hand to pay off a debt you owe a friend. If your friend now cancels (or subtracts) the debt, you are actually $5 richer: 25-(-5)=30

warning.p: For simple subtractions we don't really need the subtraction rule. For example, we can subtract 11-5 just as we did in arithmetic: 11-5=6 However, if the subtraction involves negative numbers, it is usually easier to use the subtraction rule. Thus, 11-(-5)=11+(+5)=16

assemblage.title: Look Ahead
assemblage.p: We can interpret the expression 7-9 either as a subtraction or as an addition: 7-(+9) ~~~~~ \text{or} ~~~~~ 7+(-9) Both give the same result, -2. Because addition is easier than subtraction, it is better to think of a long expression such as 7-9+12-6 as a sum of signed numbers. To do this, we add all the numbers together, and the + or - sign in front of each number tells us whether that number is positive or negative.

subsection.p: Remember that additions should be performed in order from left to right.

warning.p: The following calculation is incorrect: 16-\blert{9-4}+3~=~16-\blert{5}+3~=~11+3~=~14~~~~~~\alert {\leftarrow \text{Incorrect!}} We must perform additions and subtractions in order from left to right: \blert{16-9}-4+3~=~\blert{7}-4+3~=~3+3~=~6

subsubsection.p: Because multiplication is commutative, it is also true that -2(3)=-6. This example illustrates the following fact.

assemblage.p: The product of a positive number and a negative number is a negative number.

subsubsection.title: Case 1: The product of numbers with the same sign
subsubsection.p: You know that the product of two positive numbers is positive. It is also true that the product of two negative numbers is positive.

To understand why the product of two negative numbers is positive, you might think of canceling, or subtracting, several debts of the same amount. Or, you could observe the pattern in the lists of products below. As we move down the list, the product increases by equal amounts. \begin{aligned} 3(-2) \amp =-6 \amp 3(-5) \amp =-15\\ 2(-2) \amp =-4 \amp 2(-5) \amp =-10\\ 1(-2) \amp =-2 \amp 1(-5) \amp =-5~~\amp \leftarrow \text{Positive times negative is negative.}\\ 0(-2) \amp =-0 \amp 0(-5) \amp =0\\ -1(-2) \amp =2 \amp -1(-5) \amp =5~~\amp \leftarrow \text{Negative times negative is positive.}\\ -2(-2) \amp =4 \amp -2(-5) \amp =10\\ -3(-2) \amp =6 \amp -3(-5) \amp =15 \end{aligned} Based on the pattern in these calculations, the following rule seems reasonable.

assemblage.p: The product of two negative numbers is a positive number.

statement.p:
You can use your calculator to verify the following products.
(-6)(-3)=-28
(-2.1)(-3.4)=7.14

subsubsection.p: Now we have a pair of rules about the products of signed numbers.

ol.li: The product of two numbers with opposite signs is a negative number.
The product of two numbers with the same sign is a positive number.

subsection.title: Dividing Signed Numbers
subsection.p: Division is the inverse operation for multiplication. For example, we know that \dfrac{12}{3}=\alert{4}~~~~~~\text{because}~~~~~~3 \cdot \alert{4} = 12 Thus, every division fact can be converted into an equivalent multiplication fact. For example, \text{The division fact}~~\dfrac{\blert{400}}{16}=25~~~~\text{is equivalent to}~~~~16 \cdot 25 = \blert{400} Note that the numerator in the division fact becomes the product in the multiplication fact. The same relationship between multiplication and division holds for negative numbers as well.

statement.p:
Rewrite each division fact as a multiplication fact.
\dfrac{-144}{64}=-2.25
-36 \div \dfrac{-3}{8}=96

solution.p:
The numerator in each division fact becomes the product in the multiplication fact.
-144=-2.25(64)
-36= \dfrac{-3}{8}(96)

subsection.p: Remember that a fraction can be thought of as a division. For example, \dfrac{3}{4} means 3 \div 4, or 0.75. What about negative fractions? Because the quotient of two numbers with unlike signs is negative, the fractions \dfrac{-3}{4} and \dfrac{3}{-4} both represent the negative number -\dfrac{3}{4}. On the other hand, \dfrac{-3}{-4} is equal to the positive number \dfrac{3}{4}.
For many of the calculations in algebra, it is more convenient to write a negative fraction with the minus sign in the numerator, like this: \dfrac{-3}{4}.

subsection.title: Quotients Involving Zero
subsection.p: What is the meaning of an expression such as \dfrac{0}{2}? We can rewrite this quotient as an equivalent multiplication fact. \dfrac{0}{2}=\alert{?}~~~~\text{is equivalent to}~~~~2 \cdot \alert{?} = 0 What number can we substitute for the question mark to make 2 \cdot \alert{?} = 0 a true statement? The only solution for this equation is 0. Thus, replacing the question marks by 0 we have \dfrac{0}{2}=\alert{0}~~~~\text{because}~~~~2 \cdot \alert{0} = 0 In general, 0 divided by any (non-zero) number is 0.

Now consider a quotient with zero in the denominator, such as \dfrac{2}{0}. \dfrac{2}{0}=\alert{?}~~~~\text{is equivalent to}~~~~0 \cdot \alert{?} = 2 What number can we substitute for the question mark to make 0 \cdot \alert{?} = 2 a true statement? This equation has no solution, because 0 times any number is 0, not 2. Thus, there is no answer for the division problem \dfrac{2}{0}. We say that the quotient \dfrac{2}{0} is undefined. In general, we cannot divide any number by zero.

assemblage.title: Quotients Involving Zero
assemblage.p: If a is any nonzero number, then \dfrac{0}{a} = 0~~~~~~\text{and}~~~~~~ \dfrac{a}{0} ~~ \text{is undefined.}
